text: While social media has been recently exposed for its imperfections, the dominance of Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Facebook (FB) can not be understated. Though Twitter is a distant third competitor, there is so much fundamental potential in this platform (as I discussed recently

in "It's Time for Twitter to Change to a Subscription-Based Model") and, given the monumental rise in the share prices of some potential acquirers - Twitter has attractive optionality and a very favorable upside reward vs. downside risk at a price of $33/share.

We saw this in March and we might be seeing it today. Investing unemotionally and taking advantage of these distortions have proven to be profitable for me over time. Finally, I manage investment portfolios of long duration assets with an intermediate term time frame -

why not wait? Why be anticipatory and not react to when market prices "tell us" the trend has changed? There are a number of reasons why I am anticipatory. To begin with, I average into prices - this provides an anticipatory investor with a way of "controlling" the risk that

stocks will continue to advance. I start small, using a funnel approach as the difference between value and prices widens - shorting more when stock prices are above intrinsic value and buying more when stock prices are at a discount to intrinsic value, as I did in March.

@realmoney Jul 08, 2020 | 08:05 AM EDT DOUG KASS Anticipatory Investing Yesterday I made the considered decision to raise my net short exposure to large-sized - I may be wrong, I may be right. The investment mosaic, as I have often written, is a complicated one.

I wish, with nearly five decades of investing experiencing, I knew for sure that we were at or near a market top - but that is impossible. I didn't know the market bottomed in March for sure but I saw the indications. I have learned to look for signposts. Those signposts, have

provided me with a guide to strategy. Like my "fair market value" calculus, that assigns probabilities to 3-5 different economic and business scenarios - it becomes an "odds" bet to put it into betting jargon. As the difference between price and intrinsic value widens, upside

reward vs. downside risk deteriorates. The current setup represents a confluence of conditions: of continued individual stock speculation by the retail community, expanding investor confidence (which is the outgrowth of rising prices since the March low) an "overbought" as well

as the many coincident and forward looking factors mentioned in yesterday's opening missive. Given these factors and within the context of a 2500-3100 projected trading range and a 2750 "fair market value", I moved into a large net short exposure yesterday. Some, ask...

The @realdonaldtrump "No Apologies" Tour: Trump is nothing more than a fragile ego wrapped in pompous vanity. The best way to knock him off his game is to expose his “made-for-T.V.” persona as mere camouflage for an ignorant, unpopular blowhard mocked by all who know him. On

Tuesday, The Lincoln Project released a devastating ad entitled, “Whispers.” In the ad, the narrator speaks to Trump directly, telling him that everyone in his inner circle is laughing at him behind his back and leaking stories to the press. Ouch!! Kudos to the Lincoln Group

on its highly-effective psychological warfare. The Lincoln Group is performing a vital function; by attacking Trump and drawing fire, they are keeping Biden above the fray. Good. It’s working. Mary Trump, the president’s niece, is ready to release an account of the incredible

dysfunction of the Trump dynasty. While most of the book amounts to family gossip, there is one revelation that could be important, if true. Ms. Trump alleges that Donald Trump hired someone to take the SAT for him—thereby increasing his chances of admission to college. See CNN,

“Mary Trump's scathing book claims Trump paid someone to take his SATs.” Academic institutions frequently revoke degrees granted to graduates who cheat to gain entrance. Someone at Wharton should be taking a close look at Trump’s admissions file. Trump frequently brags that he

small-business loans went to private-equity backed chains, members of Congress.” Recipients included Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao’s family’s shipping business. Secretary Chao is married to Mitch McConnell and her family’s shipping business is headquartered in New York,

impossible to draw a meaningful conclusion from a single data point. Still, the dramatically increasing infection rates cannot be dismissed as harmless—which is the false narrative adopted by Trump and warned against by Dr. Fauci. The good news is that governors and mayors are

not listening to Trump. They are reacting to the undeniable swelling hospital admissions and surging growth in infections. Texas, Florida, Arizona, and California have all paused or reversed their plans for reopening. Against this newfound caution at the state level, Trump

began a campaign to re-open all schools by September. See NYTimes, “Trump Leans on Schools to Reopen as Virus Continues Its Spread.” The debate over opening schools is complicated, but no one can disagree that schools must use appropriate safeguards to protect students and

parents. Trump doesn’t care about schools or students; he cares about maximizing his reelection prospects by trying to reignite the economy. (“We’re very much going to put pressure on governors and everybody else to open the schools, to get them open. It’s very important.

for our country.”) Trump’s epically inept response to the pandemic continues unabated. He is treating the coronavirus as a personal affront to his reelection prospects rather than as a public health emergency. The American people are noticing. Good. In the meantime,

obvious reasons. The coronavirus is dangerous because it has managed to turn ignorance into a disease vector. Happily, for the virus, and sadly, for us, there appears to be a limitless supply of ignorance in the U.S.—courtesy of Donald Trump. Trump upped the level of ignorance

to unimaginable heights on Tuesday by announcing that the U.S. would withdraw from the World Health Organization (WHO). See WaPo, “It’s America vs. world as coronavirus spreads and hospitalizations rise.” The move makes no sense because diseases do not respect boundaries. The

best containment strategy for incipient diseases on foreign soil is for the U.S. to assist other countries in their containment efforts. Such efforts are frequently coordinated by WHO. Trump has just abandoned the first line of defense against the transmission of new diseases

into the U.S. The pandemic sets new national records for infections each day, fueled by surges in the South and West. Trump is nonetheless declaring victory because of a declining death rate despite increases in infections. On Tuesday, Dr. Anthony Fauci dismissed the declining
